tn.text: This is the next part of the story. Jesus has traveled from Jerusalem to Galilee. A crowd has followed him up a mountainside. These verses tell the setting of this part of the story. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background|Background Information]])
The phrase "these things" refers to the events in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:05:01|5:1-46]].
It is implied in the text that Jesus traveled by boat and took his disciples with him. AT: "Jesus traveled by boat with his disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"A large number of people"
This refers to the miracles that are used as evidence that God is the all-powerful one who has complete authority over everything.
The action in the story begins in verse 5.

tn.ref: Now the Passover, the Jewish festival, was near
tn.text: John briefly stops telling about the events in the story in order to give background information about when the events happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background|Background Information]])

tn.ref: But Jesus said this to test Philip, for he himself knew what he was going to do
tn.text: John briefly stops telling about the events in the story in order to explain why Jesus asked Philip where to buy bread. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background|Background Information]])
The reflexive pronoun "himself" makes it clear that the word "he" refers to Jesus. Jesus knew what he would do. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns|Reflexive Pronouns]])

tn.ref: Two hundred denarii worth of bread
tn.text: The word "denarii" is the plural of "denarius. "AT: "The amount of bread that cost two hundred days' wages."  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bmoney]])
"Five loaves of barley bread." Barley was a common grain.
A loaf of bread is a lump of dough that is shaped and baked. These were probably small dense, round loaves.

tn.ref: what are these among so many?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to emphasize that they do not have enough food to feed everyone. AT: "these few loaves and fishes are not enough to feed so many people!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"lie down"

tn.ref: Now there was a lot of grass in the place
tn.text: John briefly stops telling about the events in the story in order to give background information about the place where this event happens. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: So the men sat down, about five thousand in number
tn.text: While the crowd probably included women and children ([[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:04|6:4-5]]), here John is counting only the men.
Jesus prayed to God the Father and thanked him for the fish and the loaves.
"he" here represents "Jesus and his disciples." AT: "Jesus and his disciples gave it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
Jesus withdraws from the crowd. This is the end of the part of the story about Jesus feeding the crowd on the mountain.
"the disciples gathered"
the food that no one had eaten
Jesus feeding the 5,000 people with five barley loaves and two fish
the special prophet who Moses said would come into the world
This is the next event in the story. Jesus' disciples go out onto the lake in a boat.

tn.ref: It was dark by this time, and Jesus had not yet come to them
tn.text: Use your language's way of showing that this is background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Boats usually had two, four, or six people rowing with rowers on each side working together. Your culture may have different ways of making a boat go across a large body of water.
five or thirty stadia** - A "stadium" is 185 meters. AT: "about five or six kilometers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bdistance]])
"Stop being afraid!"

tn.ref: they were willing to receive him into the boat
tn.text: It is implied that Jesus gets into the boat. AT: "they gladly received him into the boat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"the Sea of Galilee"

tn.ref: However, there were ... the Lord had given thanks
tn.text: Use your language's way of showing that this is background information. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

Here, John provides more background information. The next day, after Jesus fed the people, some boats with people from Tiberius came to see Jesus. However, Jesus and his disciples had left the night before. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
The people go to Capernaum to find Jesus. When they see him, they start asking him questions.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].

tn.ref: eternal life which the Son of Man will give you, for God the Father has set his seal on him
tn.text: God the Father has given his approval to Jesus, the Son of Man, to give eternal life to those who believe in him.

tn.ref: Son of Man ... God the Father
tn.text: These are important titles that describe the relationship between Jesus and God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: has set his seal on him
tn.text: To "set a seal" on something means to place a mark on it to show to whom it belongs. This means that the Son belongs to the Father and that the Father approves of him in every way. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"forefathers" or "ancestors"
This refers to the place where God lives.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].

tn.ref: it is my Father who is giving you the true bread from heaven
tn.text: The "true bread" is a metaphor for Jesus. AT: "The Father gives to you the Son as the true bread from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"gives spiritual life to the world"
Here the "world" is a metonym for all of the people in the world who trust in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: I am the bread of life
tn.text: Through metaphor, Jesus compares himself with bread. Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "Just as food keeps you alive physically, I can give you spiritual life." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
This means to believe that Jesus is the Son of God, to trust him as Savior, and to live in a way that honors him.

tn.ref: Everyone whom the Father gives me will come to me
tn.text: God the Father and God the Son will save forever those who believe in Jesus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: he who comes to me I will certainly not throw out
tn.text: This sentence states the opposite of what it means for emphasis. AT: "I will keep everyone who comes to me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
Jesus continues speaking to the crowd.
"my Father, who sent me"

tn.ref: I would lose not one of all those
tn.text: Here litotes is used to emphasize that Jesus will keep everyone that God gives to him. AT: "I should keep all of them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]])
The Jewish leaders interrupt Jesus as he is speaking to the crowd.
talked unhappily

Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "I am the one who is like true bread." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:35|6:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: Is not this Jesus ... whose father and mother we know?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to emphasize that the Jewish leaders believe that Jesus is no one special. AT: "This is just Jesus, the son of Joseph, whose father and mother we know! (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: How then does he now say, 'I have come down from heaven'?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to emphasize that the Jewish leaders do not believe that Jesus came from heaven. AT: "He is lying when he says that he came from heaven!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Jesus continues speaking to the crowd and now also to the Jewish leaders.
This can mean 1) "pulls" or 2) "attracts."

tn.ref: It is written in the prophets
tn.text: This is a passive statement that can be translated in an active form. AT: "The prophets wrote" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Everyone who has heard and learned from the Father comes to me
tn.text: The Jews thought Jesus was the "son of Joseph" (see [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:41|John 6:42]]), but he is the Son of God because his Father is God, not Joseph. Those who truly learn from God the Father believe in Jesus, who is God the Son.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
Jesus now continues speaking to the crowd and the Jewish leaders.
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].

tn.ref: Not that anyone has seen the Father, except he who is from God
tn.text: Although no human who is alive on earth has seen God the Father, Jesus, the Son of God, has seen the Father.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: he who believes has eternal life
tn.text: God gives "eternal life" to those who trust in Jesus, the Son of God.

tn.ref: I am the bread of life
tn.text: Just as bread is necessary for our physical life, Jesus is necessary for our spiritual life. AT: "Just like food that keeps you alive physically, I can give you spiritual life that lasts forever." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:35|6:35]].  (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"forefathers" or "ancestors"
This refers to physical death.

Here "bread" is a metaphor that points to Jesus who is the one who gives spiritual life just as bread sustains physical life. AT: "I am like the true bread" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"live forever." Here the word "die" refers to spiritual death.
This means "the bread that causes people to live" ([[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:35|6:35]]).

tn.ref: for the life of the world
tn.text: Here "the world" is a metonym that represents the lives of all the people in the world. AT: "that will give life to all the people in the world" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Some Jews who are present begin to argue among themselves and Jesus responds to their question.

tn.ref: How can this man give us his flesh to eat?
tn.text: This remark appears in the form of a question to emphasize that the Jewish leaders are reacting negatively to what Jesus has said about "his flesh." AT: "There is no way that this man can give us his flesh to eat!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Translate this as you did in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:01:49|1:51]].

tn.ref: eat the flesh of the Son of Man and drink his blood
tn.text: Here the phrases "eat the flesh" and "drink his blood" are metaphors that show how trusting in Jesus, the Son of Man, is like receiving spiritual food and drink. AT: "receive the Son of Man just like you receive food and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: you will not have life in yourselves
tn.text: "you will not receive eternal life"
Jesus continues speaking to all those listening to him.

tn.ref: Whoever eats my flesh and drinks my blood has everlasting life
tn.text: The phrases "eats my flesh" and "drinks my blood" are metaphors. Just as one requires food and drink in order to have physical life, those who trust in Jesus will have spiritual life. AT: "whoever trusts me for their spiritual food and drink will have eternal life" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"on the day when God judges everyone"

tn.ref: my flesh is true food ... my blood is true drink
tn.text: The words "true food" and "true drink" are metaphors that mean Jesus provides spiritual food and drink to those who trust in him. Receiving Jesus in faith provides everlasting life the same way food and drink nourish the physical body. AT: "I am truly spiritual food and drink" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: remains in me, and I in him
tn.text: "has a close relationship with me"
"the one who trusts in me"
Possible meanings are 1) "the Father who gives life" or 2) "the Father who is alive."
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])

tn.ref: This is the bread that has come down from heaven
tn.text: The "bread" is a metaphor for Jesus, who has come from heaven. AT: "I am like bread that has come from heaven" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

This is a metaphor. Those who trust in Jesus for their spiritual life are like those who rely on physical bread or food for their physical lives. AT: "Whoever trusts in me" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"forefathers" or "ancestors"

tn.ref: Jesus said these things in the synagogue ... in Capernaum
tn.text: Here John gives background information about when this event happened. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
Some of the disciples ask a question and Jesus responds, as he continues speaking to the crowd.

This remark appears in the form of a question to emphasize that the disciples have difficulty understanding what Jesus has said. AT: "no one can accept it" or "it is too hard to understand!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"Does this shock you?" or "Does this upset you?"

tn.ref: Then what if you should see the Son of Man going up to where he was before?
tn.text: Jesus offers this remark in the form of a question to emphasize that his disciples will see other things that are also hard to understand. AT: "Then you will not know what to think when you see me, the Son of Man, going up into heaven!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "profit" means to cause good things to happen.
"Words" is a metonym that could possibly mean: 1) Jesus' words in [[:en:bible:notes:jhn:06:32|6:32-58]] or 2) everything Jesus teaches. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: The words that I have spoken to you
tn.text: "What I have told you"

tn.ref: are spirit, and they are life
tn.text: Possible meanings are 1) "are about the Spirit and eternal life" or 2) "are from the Spirit and give eternal life" or 3) "are about spiritual things and life."
Jesus finishes speaking to the crowd.

tn.ref: For Jesus knew from the beginning who were the ones ... who it was who would betray him
tn.text: Here John gives background information about what Jesus knew would happen. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: no one can come to me unless it is granted to him by the Father
tn.text: Whoever wants to believe must come to God through the Son. Only God the Father allows people to come to Jesus.
This is an important title for God. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:guidelines_sonofgodprinciples]])
"follow me and receive eternal life"

tn.ref: Lord, to whom shall we go?
tn.text: Simon Peter gives this remark in the form of a question to emphasize that he desires to follow only Jesus. AT: "Lord, we could never follow anyone but you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here "his disciples" refers to the general group of people who followed Jesus.
This is an ellipsis for "the twelve disciples," a specific group of twelve men who followed Jesus for his entire ministry. AT: "the twelve disciples" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
Verse 71 is not part of the main storyline as John comments on what Jesus said. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: Did not I choose you, the twelve, and one of you is a devil?
tn.text: Jesus gives this remark in the form of a question to draw attention to the fact that one of the disciples will betray him. AT: "I chose you all myself, yet one of you is a servant of Satan!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
